qas.question: What is the purpose of white-balancing?
Of incandescent lights, fluorescent lights and LEDs, which has the best color-rendering performance?
What is the color rendering index of an incandescent light?
Why do incandescent lights have superior color rendering?

answers.text: the continuous blackbody spectrum emitted from an incandescent light-bulb filament

qas.question: What is the highest possible color rendering index score?
What does not have an advantage in applications where color reproduction is important?
What is not the purpose of white-balancing?

plausible_answers.text: The color-rendering performance of incandescent lights

qas.question: What can be matched by LEDs or flourescent lights?
What does not require additional adjustments to reduce green-magenta color casts?

context: Although inefficient, <b5_0>incandescent light bulbs<b5_0/> have an advantage in applications where accurate color reproduction is important, since <a3_0>the continuous blackbody spectrum emitted from an <b8_0>incandescent light<b8_0/>-bulb filament<a3_0/> yields near-perfect color rendition, with a color rendering index of <a2_0><a4_0>100<a4_0/><a2_0/> (the best possible). White-balancing is still required <a0_0><b6_0>to avoid too "warm" or "cool" colors<b6_0/><a0_0/>, but this is a simple process that requires only the color temperature in Kelvin as input for modern, digital visual reproduction equipment such as video or still cameras unless it is completely automated. <b7_0>The color-rendering performance of <a1_0><b9_0>incandescent lights<b9_0/><b7_0/><a1_0/> cannot be matched by LEDs or fluorescent lights, although they can offer satisfactory performance for non-critical applications such as home lighting. White-balancing such lights is therefore more complicated, requiring additional adjustments to reduce for example green-magenta color casts, and even when properly white-balanced, the color reproduction will not be perfect.
